knowledges.speaker: Frannie

synsets.definition: have or possess, either in a concrete or an abstract sense
_examples: She has $1,000 in the bank
He has got two beautiful daughters
She holds a Master's degree from Harvard

synsets.definition: have as a feature
_examples: This restaurant features the most famous chefs in France

synsets.definition: go through (mental or physical states or experiences)
_examples: get an idea
experience vertigo
get nauseous
receive injuries
have a feeling

synsets.definition: have ownership or possession of
_examples: He owns three houses in Florida
How many cars does she have?

synsets.definition: cause to move; cause to be in a certain position or condition
_examples: He got his squad on the ball
This let me in for a big surprise
He got a girl into trouble

synsets.definition: serve oneself to, or consume regularly
_examples: Have another bowl of chicken soup!
I don't take sugar in my coffee

synsets.definition: have a personal or business relationship with someone
_examples: have a postdoc
have an assistant
have a lover

synsets.definition: organize or be responsible for
_examples: hold a reception
have, throw, or make a party
give a course

synsets.definition: have left
_examples: I have two years left
I don't have any money left
They have two more years before they retire

synsets.definition: be confronted with
_examples: What do we have here?
Now we have a fine mess

synsets.definition: undergo
_examples: The stocks had a fast run-up

synsets.definition: suffer from; be ill with
_examples: She has arthritis

synsets.definition: cause to do; cause to act in a specified manner
_examples: The ads induced me to buy a VCR
My children finally got me to buy a computer
My wife made me buy a new sofa

synsets.definition: receive willingly something given or offered
_examples: The only girl who would have him was the miller's daughter
I won't have this dog in my house!
Please accept my present

synsets.definition: get something; come into possession of
_examples: receive payment
receive a gift
receive letters from the front

synsets.definition: undergo (as of injuries and illnesses)
_examples: She suffered a fracture in the accident
He had an insulin shock after eating three candy bars
She got a bruise on her leg
He got his arm broken in the scuffle

synsets.definition: achieve a point or goal
_examples: Nicklaus had a 70
The Brazilian team got 4 goals
She made 29 points that day

synsets.definition: cause to be born
_examples: My wife had twins yesterday!

synsets.definition: have sex with; archaic use
_examples: He had taken this woman when she was most vulnerable

knowledges.origin_sent: Oh, I hate you, I'm pushing my Aunt Roz through Parrot Jungle and you're having sex!

knowledges.speaker: Frannie

synsets.definition: dislike intensely; feel antipathy or aversion towards
_examples: I hate Mexican food
She detests politicians

knowledges.origin_sent: Oh, I hate you, I'm pushing my Aunt Roz through Parrot Jungle and you're having sex!

synsets.definition: be cognizant or aware of a fact or a specific piece of information; possess knowledge or information about
_examples: I know that the President lied to the people
I want to know who is winning the game!
I know it's time

synsets.definition: know how to do or perform something
_examples: She knows how to knit
Does your husband know how to cook?

synsets.definition: be aware of the truth of something; have a belief or faith in something; regard as true beyond any doubt
_examples: I know that I left the key on the table
Galileo knew that the earth moves around the sun

synsets.definition: be familiar or acquainted with a person or an object
_examples: She doesn't know this composer
Do you know my sister?
We know this movie
I know him under a different name
This flower is known as a Peruvian Lily

synsets.definition: have firsthand knowledge of states, situations, emotions, or sensations
_examples: I know the feeling!
have you ever known hunger?
I have lived a kind of hell when I was a drug addict
The holocaust survivors have lived a nightmare
I lived through two divorces

synsets.definition: accept (someone) to be what is claimed or accept his power and authority
_examples: The Crown Prince was acknowledged as the true heir to the throne
We do not recognize your gods

synsets.definition: have fixed in the mind
_examples: I know Latin
This student knows her irregular verbs
Do you know the poem well enough to recite it?

synsets.definition: have sexual intercourse with
_examples: This student sleeps with everyone in her dorm
Adam knew Eve
Were you ever intimate with this man?

synsets.definition: know the nature or character of
_examples: we all knew her as a big show-off

synsets.definition: be able to distinguish, recognize as being different
_examples: The child knows right from wrong

synsets.definition: perceive as familiar
_examples: I know this voice!

synsets.definition: carry out
_examples: take action
take steps
take vengeance

synsets.definition: require (time or space)
_examples: It took three hours to get to work this morning
This event occupied a very short time

synsets.definition: take somebody somewhere
_examples: We lead him to our chief
can you take me to the main entrance?
He conducted us to the palace

synsets.definition: get into one's hands, take physically
_examples: Take a cookie!
Can you take this bag, please

synsets.definition: take on a certain form, attribute, or aspect
_examples: His voice took on a sad tone
The story took a new turn
he adopted an air of superiority
She assumed strange manners
The gods assume human or animal form in these fables

synsets.definition: interpret something in a certain way; convey a particular meaning or impression
_examples: I read this address as a satire
How should I take this message?
You can't take credit for this!

synsets.definition: take something or somebody with oneself somewhere
_examples: Bring me the box from the other room
Take these letters to the boss
This brings me to the main point

synsets.definition: take into one's possession
_examples: We are taking an orphan from Romania
I'll take three salmon steaks

synsets.definition: travel or go by means of a certain kind of transportation, or a certain route
_examples: He takes the bus to work
She takes Route 1 to Newark

synsets.definition: pick out, select, or choose from a number of alternatives
_examples: Take any one of these cards
Choose a good husband for your daughter
She selected a pair of shoes from among the dozen the salesgirl had shown her

synsets.definition: receive willingly something given or offered
_examples: The only girl who would have him was the miller's daughter
I won't have this dog in my house!
Please accept my present

synsets.definition: assume, as of positions or roles
_examples: She took the job as director of development
he occupies the position of manager
the young prince will soon occupy the throne

synsets.definition: take into consideration for exemplifying purposes
_examples: Take the case of China
Consider the following case

synsets.definition: require as useful, just, or proper
_examples: It takes nerve to do what she did
success usually requires hard work
This job asks a lot of patience and skill
This position demands a lot of personal sacrifice
This dinner calls for a spectacular dessert
This intervention does not postulate a patient's consent

synsets.definition: experience or feel or submit to
_examples: Take a test
Take the plunge

synsets.definition: make a film or photograph of something
_examples: take a scene
shoot a movie

synsets.definition: remove something concrete, as by lifting, pushing, or taking off, or remove something abstract
_examples: remove a threat
remove a wrapper
Remove the dirty dishes from the table
take the gun from your pocket
This machine withdraws heat from the environment

synsets.definition: serve oneself to, or consume regularly
_examples: Have another bowl of chicken soup!
I don't take sugar in my coffee

synsets.definition: accept or undergo, often unwillingly
_examples: We took a pay cut

synsets.definition: make use of or accept for some purpose
_examples: take a risk
take an opportunity

synsets.definition: take by force
_examples: Hitler took the Baltic Republics
The army took the fort on the hill

synsets.definition: occupy or take on
_examples: He assumes the lotus position
She took her seat on the stage
We took our seats in the orchestra
She took up her position behind the tree
strike a pose

synsets.definition: admit into a group or community
_examples: accept students for graduate study
We'll have to vote on whether or not to admit a new member

synsets.definition: ascertain or determine by measuring, computing or take a reading from a dial
_examples: take a pulse
A reading was taken of the earth's tremors

synsets.definition: be a student of a certain subject
_examples: She is reading for the bar exam

synsets.definition: take as an undesirable consequence of some event or state of affairs
_examples: the accident claimed three lives
The hard work took its toll on her

synsets.definition: head into a specified direction
_examples: The escaped convict took to the hills
We made for the mountains

synsets.definition: point or cause to go (blows, weapons, or objects such as photographic equipment) towards
_examples: Please don't aim at your little brother!
He trained his gun on the burglar
Don't train your camera on the women
Take a swipe at one's opponent

synsets.definition: be seized or affected in a specified way
_examples: take sick
be taken drunk

synsets.definition: have with oneself; have on one's person
_examples: She always takes an umbrella
I always carry money
She packs a gun when she goes into the mountains

synsets.definition: engage for service under a term of contract
_examples: We took an apartment on a quiet street
Let's rent a car
Shall we take a guide in Rome?

synsets.definition: receive or obtain regularly
_examples: We take the Times every day

synsets.definition: buy, select
_examples: I'll take a pound of that sausage

synsets.definition: to get into a position of having, e.g., safety, comfort
_examples: take shelter from the storm

synsets.definition: have sex with; archaic use
_examples: He had taken this woman when she was most vulnerable

synsets.definition: lay claim to; as of an idea
_examples: She took credit for the whole idea

synsets.definition: be designed to hold or take
_examples: This surface will not take the dye

synsets.definition: be capable of holding or containing
_examples: This box won't take all the items
The flask holds one gallon

synsets.definition: develop a habit
_examples: He took to visiting bars

synsets.definition: proceed along in a vehicle
_examples: We drive the turnpike to work

synsets.definition: obtain by winning
_examples: Winner takes all
He took first prize

synsets.definition: be stricken by an illness, fall victim to an illness
_examples: He got AIDS
She came down with pneumonia
She took a chill
